title: 115_s1685
content: The "Credit Score Competition Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for credit score validation and the validation process. The "Credit Score Competition Act of 2017" amends the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act to allow Fannie Mae to condition the purchase of residential mortgages on the borrower providing a validated credit score. The corporation must establish a process to validate and approve credit scoring models, complying with standards set by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The credit score must be used by all automated underwriting systems and procedures for purchasing residential mortgages. The corporation must validate and approve credit scoring models based on criteria like integrity, reliability, and accuracy. Developers can submit applications for model validation, and the corporation must make a determination before a set date. The corporation must validate and approve credit scoring models based on criteria like integrity, reliability, and accuracy. Developers can submit applications for model validation, and the corporation must make a determination before a set date, with possible extensions granted upon request. The corporation must provide notice of the application status within 60 days and reasons for disapproval if applicable. The corporation must update the validation and approval process for credit scores as required by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. Freddie Mac is authorized to use credit scores in purchasing residential mortgages. The Corporation may require a validated and approved credit score for a borrower when purchasing a residential mortgage under this section. The credit score predicts credit behaviors, including default, and must be derived from an approved credit scoring model. The Corporation must publicly describe the validation and approval process for credit scoring models. The Corporation must validate and approve credit scoring models for use in purchasing residential mortgages. The process includes evaluating criteria for model integrity, reliability, and accuracy to ensure safe and sound operations. The Corporation validates and approves credit scoring models for safe mortgage operations. Developers can submit applications for model validation within 180 days. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency may grant up to 2 extensions of 30 days each for application deadlines, upon request with good cause. The Corporation must notify applicants of their application status within 60 days and provide reasons for disapproval within 30 days. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency has the authority to require the Corporation to update the validation and approval process for credit scores as needed to comply with established standards. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency has the authority to establish regulations for the use of credit scores by enterprises, with the amendments taking effect 180 days after enactment.
